docs.lead_paragraph: A settlement was reached yesterday between the Museum of Modern Art and the union that includes some of its curators, librarians, sales people, graphic designers and conservators. They have been working without a contract since Nov. 1. On Dec. 17, they staged a one-day strike. Under a new three-year contract, the members of the Professional and Administrative Staff Association, known as Pasta, will receive across-the-board raises of 4 percent in the first year (retroactive to Nov. 1,), 3.2 percent in the second year and 3 percent the third.

headline.main: Union at the Modern Agrees To a Three-Year Contract

docs.abstract: Museum of Modern Art and union, Professional and Administrative Staff Assn (Pasta), reach settlement on three-year contract (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Loses 92.75 Points, Falling Below 7,000 Stocks tumbled in what some analysts saw as a natural retreat for an increasingly expensive market. The Dow industrials fell 92.75 points, to 6,927.38, after being down by 114 points at one point late in the session.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today prohibited health maintenance organizations from limiting what doctors may tell Medicaid patients about treatment options. And he urged Congress to guarantee similar protections for more than 100 million Americans with private insurance. In December, the Clinton Administration said H.M.O.'s and other health plans might not limit what doctors tell Medicare patients about treatment options. Nearly five million elderly people, about 13 percent of Medicare beneficiaries, are in H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: Clinton Prohibits H.M.O. Limit on Advice to Medicaid Patients

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Washington to Boycott Cuba Trade Law Hearings A senior Administration official said the United States ''will not show up'' at international hearings on the legitimacy of Washington's embargo of Cuba. The declaration came hours after the World Trade Organization named a panel of judges to hear a European challenge to the embargo. A1 Simple Memorial for Deng A simple memorial ceremony will be held for Deng Xiaoping in the Great Hall of the People on Tuesday, China announced. Some 10,000 party loyalists, friends and family members will be invited, said the funeral committee, headed by President Jiang Zemin, above. The new leadership said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's visit to Beijing on Monday would take place as planned. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Sunshine bleached Third Avenue in the South Bronx as Sharon Fields, a 26-year-old rookie police officer, walked her beat on June 15, 1984. Shoppers buzzed along the sidewalks of the commercial strip known as the Hub. She was glad to be out in the spring air. A block away, she spotted Officer Juan Andino, one of the nice guys in the precinct. She walked toward him, looking forward to a chat. She saw that Officer Andino had a man by the arm -- a shoplifter, she guessed. She followed them to Eye Encounter, an optical shop near 149th Street but waited outside, figuring the situation was under control.

headline.main: Shattered by the Shooting That Made Her a Hero
headline.kicker: The Neediest Cases: Officer Needs Assistance

docs.abstract: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Sharon Fields, former New York City police officer who was first woman to receive department's Medal of Honor; Fields retired on disability after she witnessed fatal shooting of colleague in South Bronx; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal law protected workers from retaliation for filing complaints about discrimination on the job, even if the retaliation takes the form of a bad job recommendation after the worker is no longer employed. The decision, written by Justice Clarence Thomas, clarified an important provision of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, interpreting in favor of employees an imprecise phrase that had been the subject of dispute among the lower Federal courts.

headline.main: Justices Say Ban on Bias Forbids Retaliation, Even Against Ex-Employees

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules unanimously that Federal law bars employer from retaliating against former worker who filed bias complaint by giving worker bad job recommendation; Justice Clarence Thomas writes decision in suit by former Shell Oil Co worker Charles T Robinson Sr against Shell; Court rules unanimously that taxpayer's mental incapacity does not excuse delay in filing for refund; Court hears arguments on validity of $1.3 billion settlement by which 20 companies that made asbestos limited their financial liability to workers exposed to asbestos who are not yet ill; appeals court overturned settlement (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal law protected workers from retaliation for filing complaints about discrimination on the job, even if the retaliation takes the form of a bad job recommendation after the worker is no longer...

docs.lead_paragraph: William Jordan, a North Carolina doctor, thought he was helping to elect Republican United States senators when he made a $50,000 campaign donation last October. After all, Dr. Jordan wrote his check to the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which is headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and whose mission is raising millions of dollars for Republican candidates for the Senate.

headline.main: D'Amato Converted Donations To Help New York Candidates

docs.abstract: Sen Alfonse D'Amato, champion fund-raiser for Republican Party, has used labyrinth of committees and financial transfers to shift funds, given by donors to National Republican Senatorial Committee for US Senate campaigns, into campaign war chests of Gov George E Pataki and other New York State politicians; worked around constraints of state and Federal campaign finance laws that put limits on direct donations to candidates, converting large contributions to national account into donations to specific New York State races, where state law tightly restricts how much how much any individual can give; he denies wrongdoing, but acknowledges few donors were told about check transfers; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Earth Pledge Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded and led by the New York labor lawyer Theodore Kheel (inset), is organizing a collective purchasing program aimed at freelancers who work in new media areas in New York City. The goal is to be able to offer health insurance at a reasonable cost to freelancers and allow them to take advantage of discounts for software, computers and office supplies. Eventually, the program may also include a pension plan, said Leslie Hoffman, executive director of Earth Pledge.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a plan that health experts greeted as brilliant and bizarre, Federal regulators announced yesterday that for the next six years they would pay New York State hospitals not to train physicians. Just as the Federal Government for many years paid corn farmers to let fields lie fallow, 41 of New York's teaching hospitals will be paid $400 million to not cultivate so many new doctors, their main cash crop.

headline.main: U.S. to Pay New York Hospitals Not to Train Doctors, Easing Glut

docs.abstract: Federal regulators plan to pay 41 of New York State's teaching hospitals $400 million over next six years not to train physicians; hope to stem growing surplus of doctors nationwide and save Government money; some hospital executives elsewhere voice concern that Health Care Financing Administration may be playing favorites with New York hospitals because of political connections and financial clout; under new program, hospitals will reduce number of residents in training by 20 percent to 25 percent over next six years, resulting in 2,000 fewer residents in state; in exchange Medicare will initially continue payments to participating hospitals as if doctors were still there, slowly phasing payments out during period; state trains 15 percent of nation's doctors, making it by far country's leading producer of new physicians; plan represents Godsend to city's cash-starved hospitals, struggling to trim staffs and adapt to world of managed care (M)
docs.snippet: In a plan that health experts greeted as brilliant and bizarre, Federal regulators announced yesterday that for the next six years they would pay New York State hospitals not to train physicians.    Just as the Federal Government for many years paid...
docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Clinton Administration officials urged Congress today to repeal a new law that makes it a Federal crime to dispose of assets to qualify for Medicaid coverage of nursing home expenses. They said that such abuses were not common. Medicaid helps pay the bills for two-thirds of the 1.6 million people in nursing homes in the United States. Families can easily exhaust their assets on nursing home care because the costs average more than $100 a day -- and much more in urban areas like New York City.

headline.main: Repeal Urged for Law on Giving Away Assets to Get Medicaid

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration urges Congress to repeal new law that makes it Federal crime to dispose of assets to qualify for Medicaid coverage of nursing home expenditures; argues that such abuses are not common; Medicaid helps pay bills for two-thirds of 1.6 million people in nursing homes in US many of whom can easily exhaust assets since care averages more than $100 per day---and much more in urban areas such as New York City (M)
